questions.question: Question 1: When do germ cells appear in the yolk sac?
questions.explanation: Germ cells appear in the yolk sac in the 3rd week. The sequence of events in primordial germ cell formation and migration are: • 2nd week - Germ cells are formed in the epiblast. • 3rd week - Germ cells move through the primitive streak and migrate to the wall of the yolk sac. • 4th week - Germ cells begin to migrate from the yolk sac to gonads. • 5th week - Germ cell migration is complete. Gametes are derived from these primordial germ cells.

questions.question: Question 2: When does the ovary contain the maximum number of oogonia?
questions.explanation:
The ovary contains the maximum number of oogonia at the 5th month of intrauterine life. The 
number of oogonia is estimated to be 7 million. Oogenesis is the process wherein oogonia differentiate into mature oocytes. It begins before birth. 
At birth, there are approximately 2 million primordial follicles. At the initiation of puberty, the 
follicle count is less than 400,000, of which less than 500 are destined to ovulate. Every month, 
15–20 follicles are released, out of which one matures to form the ovum.

questions.question:
Question 3: A man with oligospermia has completed his course of hormonal treatment. After how many 
days will you test his sperm count?
questions.explanation:
The sperm count is tested 80-90 days after hormonal treatment, as the average time is taken for 
spermatogenesis is 74 days, and approximately 14 days to reach the ejaculatory ducts. The effect of hormonal therapy on the early phase of spermatogenesis is reflected in the ejaculated 
sperm concentration after three months. Spermatogenesis is the process of the formation of sperms from spermatogonia. Approximately 
100 million sperms are produced daily. In patients diagnosed with oligospermia, hormonal treatment is carried out using FSH, hCG, or 
testosterone. Improvements in sperm count can take a few months, hence the course is usually for 
3-6 months. Normal spermatogenesis occurs after this time period. Spermiogenesis refers to the series of changes that occur in the formation of spermatozoa from 
spermatids. These are: • Acrosome formation 38 
Sold by @itachibot • Condensation of the nucleus • Formation of the neck, middle piece, and tail • Shedding of cytoplasm as residual bodies Complete motility is obtained in the epididymis.

questions.question: Question 4: What is the time taken for capacitation of the sperm?
questions.explanation:
The time taken for the capacitation of sperms is 6-8 hours (approximately 7 hours). Sperms have to undergo two changes in the female reproductive tract to be able to fertilise the 
ovum: 1) Capacitation • It is the functional maturation of the spermatozoa. • It occurs in the fallopian tube and involves epithelial interactions between the sperm and the 
mucosal surface of the tube. • The glycoprotein coat and seminal plasma proteins are removed. • Only capacitated sperms can pass through the corona cells and undergo the acrosomal reaction. 2) Acrosomal reaction • It occurs after binding to zona pellucida, induced by zona proteins. • Enzymes such as acrosin and trypsin-like protein are released to penetrate the zona pellucida • Ca2+ plays an important role. 39 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following statements is true about the resumption of meiosis-I?
questions.explanation: Meiosis-I in the primary oocyte is resumed after LH surge.

questions.question: Question 6: In which of the following steps does reductional division occur?
questions.explanation:
Meiosis I or reductional division occurs in the transition from primary spermatocyte to secondary 
spermatocyte. Meiosis takes place in germ cells to generate male and female gametes. Meiosis involves two 
stages of cell division, namely, meiosis I and II. 40 
Sold by @itachibot Meiosis I produces two haploid cells. Because the ploidy is reduced from diploid to haploid, 
meiosis I is referred to as a reductional division. Meiosis II is an equational division analogous to 
mitosis, resulting in the creation of four haploid daughter cells.

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following is incorrect about the primary oocyte?

options.a: It is formed after meiosis I

questions.explanation:
The secondary oocyte is formed after meiosis I. Primordial germ cells divide by mitosis to form oogonia. The majority of the oogonia divide by 
mitosis, however, some enter meiosis I and are arrested in the diplotene stage of prophase and are 
now called primary oocytes. Primary oocytes have not yet completed meiosis, hence they are 
diploid. The primary oocyte along with surrounding epithelial cells forms the primordial follicle. Meiosis I is completed after LH surge during puberty. Hence at the completetion of meiosis I, 
secondary oocyte is produced. 41 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 8: An embryologist is preparing embryos for implantation. When is zona hatching expected to 
occur?
questions.explanation:
Zona hatching occurs at around 5 days after fertilization. Fertilization is divided into the following phases: • Penetration of the corona radiata • Penetration of the zona pellucida • Fusion of the oocyte and sperm cell membranes After fertilisation, the zygote differentiates to form the morula and then the blastocyst. The zona 
pellucida disappears at this stage, which is called zona hatching. The trophoblasts (outer cell 
mass) are now able to associate with the endometrium during implantation.

questions.question:
Question 9: You are performing intrauterine insemination during the ovulatory period in a patient with 
infertility. When will you expect implantation to occur?
questions.explanation:
The fertilized ovum implants by 6–10 days in the uterine cavity. Implantation involves: • Apposition: Initial contact of the blastocyst to the uterine wall • Adhesion: Increased physical contact between the blastocyst and uterine epithelium • Invasion: Penetration and invasion of syncytiotrophoblast and cytotrophoblasts into the 
endometrium A successful implantation requires receptive endometrium primed with estrogen and 
progesterone released by the corpus luteum. 42 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 10: The following figure shows the transverse section of the uterus with an implanted zygote. 
Identify structure A.
questions.explanation:
In the given image, the decidua basalis is marked as A. This part of the decidua forms the 
placenta. Implantation occurs 6 to 7 days after fertilization. After implantation, the endometrium is called 
the decidua. It is of the following types: • Decidua basalis - present over chorion frondosum. Decidua basalis and chorion frondosum form 
the placenta. • Decidua capsularis - present over abembryonic pole. • Decidua parietalis - present on the opposite side of the uterus. The villi cover the entire surface of the chorion during the early weeks. As the fetus grows, the villi 
on the embryonic pole continue to grow, giving rise to the chorion frondosum. At 
the abembryonic pole, the villi degenerate. By the third month, this side of the chorion becomes 
smooth, and is called the chorion laeve. 43 
Sold by @itachibot As the fetus grows, the chorion laeve comes into contact with the decidua parietalis on the 
opposite side of the uterus, and fusion occurs. Thus, the uterine lumen is obliterated. The amnion 
and chorion fuse, to form the amniochorionic membrane. Rupture of the amniochorionic 
membrane during labor is called 'breaking of waters'. Note: Superfetation can theoretically occur till the time the uterine lumen is not obliterated.

questions.question:
Question 11: 34 
Sold by @itachibot What do the Langhans cells form?
questions.explanation:
Langhans cells form the cytotrophoblast. The cells of the blastocyst differentiate into an outer trophectoderm and an inner cell mass. The trophectoderm is further differentiated into: • An inner mononuclear cellular layer called cytotrophoblast or Langhans layer made of Langhans 
cells. • An outer layer of multinucleated syncytium called syncytiotrophoblast. The blastomere further divides to form the morula. 44 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 12: Identify the structure marked A.
questions.explanation:
The structure marked A is primary oocyte. Primary oocytes are the germ cells seen in the 
medullary region of the ovary. These enlarge at the beginning of the growth phase. During this cell growth period, many oocytes undergo degeneration, both before and after birth. A 
single layer of flattened follicular cells that were derived originally from the germinal epithelium 
soon surrounds the primary oocytes. The structure that is formed is now called a primordial 
follicle. These are seen first in the medulla and later in the cortex. 45 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 13: In which part of the fallopian tube does fertilization occur?
questions.explanation:
Fertilization usually occurs in the ampulla of the fallopian tube. During ovulation, the ovum is released and it enters the fallopian tube. It is propelled towards the 
uterine cavity by the peristaltic action of the fallopian tubes, prostaglandins in the male seminal 
fluid and oxytocin. It can only be fertilized within 24 hours of ovulation. If coitus takes place 
during this period, the spermatozoa swimming up into the tubes meet the ovum in the ampulla.

questions.question:
Question 14: A newborn is admitted to the NICU with the following teratoma. Which embryonic layers is 
this derived from?
questions.explanation:
The given image shows an oropharygeal teratoma, which contains derivatives from all three germ 
layers. The tumor may include gut, bone, skin, and teeth. These tumors arise from pluripotent stem cells 
that differentiate into any of three germ layers forming tissues of all three germ layers.

questions.question:
Question 15: Identify the structure marked as A. 36 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The structure marked A is the allantois. The posterior wall of the yolk sac forms the allantois on the 16th day of development. Its distal 
portion forms the urachus which forms the median umbilical ligament. The given image shows an embryo at the end of the third week. 46 
Sold by @itachibot Amniotic cavity Head end 
of embryo Tail end Future 
umblical cord Allantois Heart Primordial germ 
cells in wall 
of yolk sac Yolk sac 47 
Sold by @itachibot Maternal Pelvis and Fetal Skull
